sect1.title: Impact of Gender, Race, Culture, Age, and Other Aspects of Diversity

sect2.title: Ethnicity and Culture
sect2.para: Recent studies studies suggested that ED prevalence among African American, Latinx, Asian, Pacific Islander, and/or Native American ethnic minority groups is comparable to, or higher than, ED rates among non-Latinx European Americans (Cheng et al., 2019 ). Although members of ethnic-racial minority groups are not protected from developing an ED, they are less likely to receive a referral for ED assessment or treatment than European Americans (Moreno et al., 2023 ). Even when referred for treatment, ethnic and racial minorities are less likely to utilize mental-health resources than their European-American counterparts. The lack of treatment referral and treatment receipt in ethnic-minority groups is theorized to be the result result of increased stigmatization of mental health services (Misra et al., 2021 ). Another important consideration is the potential need to include the family in the assessment and treatment process. For example, excluding family members from clinical services could violate the Latinx cultural value of familismo, which refers to a strong identification and attachment to nuclear and and extended families. Finally, therapists should be aware of cultural adaptations and tailor their intake interview to assess culturally relevant issues that may maintain ED behaviors. For example, Exum et al. ( 2022 ) theorized theorized that for Black women, discrimination, strong black woman identification (cultural and societal expectations of strength), and culturally specific body-image ideals may lead to stress. In turn, ED behaviors may serve as a maladaptive coping mechanism for mitigating the high stress that Black women are exposed to in society.

Patients who identify as a member member of an ethnic-racial minority group who appear for services may be more likely to present with a higher level of psychiatric impairment and disorder severity (Burke et al., 2021 ). High severity may be due to cultural stigma and discrimination, which may lead some individuals to live with ED symptoms longer and wait to seek treatment (or not receive appropriate referrals) until they are severely impaired.

Despite having greater greater symptom severity upon initial treatment presentation, certain minority groups may simultaneously report lower body-image concerns than their European American counterparts. Researchers suggested that potential differences in body image disturbance may be due to cultural preference for “curvier” body sizes among members of certain ethnic and racial groups (Lowy et al., 2021 ). East Asian individuals are likely to prioritize body image based on thinness, and culturally important features, such as eye shape and and complexion (Brady et al., 2017 ). South Asian individuals may report body image disturbance disturbance due to pressures to achieve competing appearance ideals, weight stigma from multiple sources (e. g., mothers, relatives, and “aunties”), and pressures to possess light skin (Goel et al., 2021 ). Finally, for first-generation ethnic-racial minorities, clinicians should evaluate the role of acculturation in the onset and maintenance of ED symptoms.

Assessment Tip: During assessment and treatment, it is important to consider the cultural practices of the population. Although something may seem abnormal or maladaptive to you, it may be common practice in certain cultures. Racism, discrimination, and sexism are also risk factors for maladaptive behaviors, so maintaining cultural humility and working to the best of one’s ability to understand the the client’s experience is critical.

sect2.title: Religion
sect2.para: Religious Religious diets, practices, and rituals can impact ED assessment and treatment. It is crucial to disentangle religious modesty from body avoidance in various populations. For For example, tzniut tzniut (the character trait of modesty in dressing and behavior) is an important tenet in the Orthodox Jewish religion Orthodox Jewish religion . Similarly, it is important to parse apart motivations for underlying eating behaviors. For example, Ramadan and Navratri are culturally sanctioned periods of religious fasting. One the one hand, it is not appropriate to pathologize culturally sanctioned eating behaviors. On the other hand, it is important to recognize that weight- and shape-related motivations for dietary restraint can co-exist with religious motivations for fasting. Thus, therapists should not assume that religion is the primary or only reason motivating fasting. We recommend that therapists ask if “any small part” of the behavior is also motivated by the desire to lose weight or compensate for an eating episode. If a client indicates that a secondary motivation of religious fasting or body avoidance is to accommodate the ED, then this provides provides the therapist with an opportunity to align the client’s behaviors with their stated values.

Assessment Tip: When working with clients of varying religious backgrounds, it is important to practice cultural humility by doing personal work to learn more about the client’s religion, consulting with spiritual leaders, and identifying ways to honor religious practices, while also promoting ED recovery. Including religious leaders as partners during assessment and treatment can help ensure that conceptualization and and treatment are culturally responsive.

sect2.title: Food Insecurity
sect2.para: EDs EDs are frequently elevated among people with food insecurity (Becker et al., 2019 ). Food insecurity is defined by the US Department of Agriculture as a condition of limited or uncertain access to adequate food (National Research Council, 2006 ). Food insecurity is disproportionately experienced by people with lower incomes, people from minoritized racial and ethnic groups, people with disabilities, and people who identify as a sexual minority, which may be attributed to factors such as worsened socioeconomic conditions, structural racism, and discrimination. Although the mechanisms linking food insecurity to ED psychopathology are still being evaluated, one theory posits that individuals with food insecurity experience “feast-or-famine” cycles (Dinour et al., 2007 ), which may drive patterns of dietary restriction and binge eating. According to this model, during during times of lower food availability, some household members may restrict food intake out of necessity or to make food available to other members of the household. When food is more abundant, such as when financial resources become available, people in the feast-or-famine cycle feast-or-famine cycle may be more likely to binge eat. Traditional assessments for EDs have focused on shape/weight-related motivations for dietary restraint, with no current measures specifically assessing food insecurity as a motivation for dietary restraint. It is, thus, important to ask clients if dietary restriction is due (at least in part) to limited food availability. Clinicians should seek to understand how dietary restraint that is motivated by desire to change weight or shape may interact with food insecurity.

Assessment Tip: When assessing among people with food insecurity, therapists should nonjudgmentally evaluate the contexts during which ED behaviors occur to develop case conceptualizations that capture all potential mechanisms.

sect2.title: Cisgender Women and Men
sect2.para: Women have have a higher prevalence of EDs than men. It could could be that ED behaviors are less likely to be identified in men, that men may not recognize that they have an ED and are less likely to seek treatment, or that the current diagnostic system does not accurately capture the experience of EDs in men. Compared to other EDs, men are most likely to be diagnosed with BED and to report overeating. Men are more likely to endorse a desire for a muscular figure, consistent with Western body ideals. To this end, men with EDs may strive to gain muscle mass or have a lean body (with low percent body fat) to enhance the appearance of muscularity.

sect2.title: Persons Who Are Transgender or Gender Diverse
sect2.para: Gender plays plays a critical role in how EDs are experienced. The experience of gender for many people is fluid and better defined as a continuous variable in which a person can identify anywhere along the continuum continuum of “feminine” and “masculine.” We define the term transgender broadly to be inclusive of any person whose gender identity does not match the gender that would correspond with their sex assigned at birth. Transgender individuals are more susceptible to EDs than cisgender individuals. Within the transgender community, 17.7% of individuals have elevated ED symptomatology, and individuals assigned female at birth are especially at risk for developing an ED during their lifetime (Rasmussen et al., 2023 ). Elevated ED symptoms may also intersect with gender dysphoria in transgender persons. For example, levels of body dissatisfaction dissatisfaction are high among transgender individuals who believe that their body is too feminine (i. e., perception of having too large of breasts, hips, or proportion of body fat as compared to muscle) or too masculine (i. e., perception of having too much muscle mass and an undesired V-shaped torso) (Cusack et al., 2022 ). To influence their body weight or shape in a way that is more personally desirable, transgender individuals may engage in disordered eating and unhealthy exercise that could result in the development of an ED (Mirabella et al., 2020 ). Gender-affirming treatments (e. g., hormone therapy, surgical interventions), therefore, may play a critical role in improving ED symptoms, but gender-affirming medical treatments are not sufficient stand-alone ED interventions (Rasmussen et al., 2023 ).

Assessment Tip: When working working with clients, it is critical to ask about their pronouns and to use these pronouns in every subsequent interaction. Finally, careful assessment of body image may be helpful in working with persons who identify as nonbinary or transgender, particularly to determine to what degree gender dysphoria may influence the ED.

sect2.title: Sexual Orientation
sect2.para: Recent studies studies have found the prevalence of DSM-5-TR EDs among individuals who identify as a sexual minority is 1.9–3.6 times higher than in individuals who identify as heterosexual (Kamody et al., 2020 ). Sexual minority men and women are reported to experience greater overall ED symptoms, in addition to increased risk risk factors that can worsen symptoms, such as discrimination, prejudice, internalized homophobia, and sexual violence (Kamody et al., 2020 ). Overall, gay and bisexual men are more likely to report ED symptoms compared to heterosexual men. Bisexual women are more likely to report binge-eating, purging, and dieting.

To facilitate effective effective assessment and treatment, it is important for clinicians to assess social support and how these systems influence eating pathology for sexual minority individuals. Strong social support and engagement within the lesbian community are reported as protective factors for lesbian women, whereas greater involvement in the gay community was identified as a risk factor for eating concerns for gay and bisexual men (Morrison et al., 2020 ). Although social support can fluctuate during the “coming out” process, “coming out” can positively influence ED symptom severity.

Assessment Tip: When assessing for EDs in a sexual-minority population it is important to consider social and environmental stressors and their impact on the client’s life experience and ED diagnosis. Sexual minority individuals may strive for a body ideal that is different from what a heterosexual individual with body body image concerns may idealize.

sect2.title: Age
sect2.para: ED onset most typically typically occurs in adolescent- and young-adult populations (Hudson et al., 2007 ). However, recent research has shown that maladaptive eating behaviors and cognitions occur at significant rates among children and older adults (Campbell & Peebles, 2014 ; Lapid et al., 2010 ). According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ( 2018 ), about 42% of children and adolescents between grades nine through 12, reported feeling too fat or wanting to be thinner, and about 81% reported being afraid of becoming fat as early as 10-years-old (CDC, 2018). Additionally, about 5% reported taking diet pills that were not prescribed by a doctor, vomiting or taking laxatives (4.4%), and/or not eating for 24 h or more (13%; Hudson et al., 2007 ; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2018 ).

Assessment Tip: Clinicians should also assess body image in the context of normal shape and weight changes that occur during development development (e. g., during adolescence, menopause, or through the normal process of aging).

sect2.title: Athletes
sect2.para: Among Norwegian elite athletes athletes , the estimated prevalence of EDs is up to 32.8%, and rates of EDs are higher in athletes relative to non-athletes, which is consistent with findings from an early meta-analysis (Torstveit et al., 2008 ). In the United States, athletes were more likely to screen positive for an ED compared to non-athletes. Some research suggests that not all athletes are equally susceptible to developing an ED. For example, a meta-analytic review of ED psychopathology in female athletes vs. non-athletes found that athletes participating in weight class sports and sports emphasizing thinness/leanness (e. g., rowing, cross country, figure skating, etc.) had higher levels of disordered eating relative to other sport types types (e. g., volleyball, basketball; Chapa et al., 2022 ). Among athletes, some symptoms of eating disorders may be more prevalent (e. g., excessive exercise) or less prevalent (e. g., body dissatisfaction) relative to non-athletes (Chapa et al., 2022 ). Athletes, especially athletes participating in sports that focus on thinness/leanness may be exposed to additional risk factors that non-athletes or athletes participating in other sports do not encounter; these additional risk factors include: (1) the belief that sport performance is optimal at a lower weight, (2) revealing uniforms, and (3) reinforcement from judges and/or coaches for certain body types. Due to the serious health risks associated with EDs (e. g., irregular heart rate, imbalanced electrolytes, bone deterioration), athletes who continue to participate in their sport with an ED are highly susceptible to physical injury, anemia, chronic fatigue, irregular menstruation (for women), and other serious medical problems due to relative energy deficiency syndrome (or REDs).

Identifying unhealthy unhealthy exercise behaviors in athletes might be challenging because: (1) physical activity and sport participation are typically considered healthful behaviors and (2) athletes who exercise more than their coach recommends or when sick or injured may appear dedicated to their sport and/or team (and might even be rewarded). However, when patients engage in exercise past the point of their physical capacity, despite sickness or injury, against medical advice, or to compensate for an eating episode, it is unhealthful. Exercising more than recommended by coaches, against medical (or sport trainer) advice, or when sick or injured may be suggestive of an underlying ED rather than indicative of sport commitment.
Assessment Tip: When working with athletes, it is also recommended that you ask for collateral information from coaches, coaches’ assistants assistants , and/or sports medicine staff.

sect2.title: Individuals in the Perinatal Period
sect2.para: Elevated rates of EDs during the perinatal period could be due to substantial changes in human chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, progesterone, oxytocin, prolactin, body weight and shape, appetite, social roles, and sleep, all of which are contributors to an ED. Women who do not meet the increased increased metabolic/caloric needs of pregnancy and postpartum (including while breastfeeding) may experience intense hunger which may eventually lead to overeating and could trigger a binge-restrict pattern. Other ED behaviors could be motivated, in part, by societal societal pressure to return to pre-pregnancy weight/shape.

EDs that occur during pregnancy may affect both maternal and fetal health outcomes. Maternal EDs are associated with heightened rates of birth complications, cesarean delivery, low birth weight, and intrauterine growth growth restriction. Mothers with a current or past ED may have an elevated risk of developing postpartum depression and anxiety.

Assessment Tip: Given the significant risks related to perinatal EDs, it is imperative to assess for disordered eating during and after pregnancy. Assessment or screening could be implemented in routine health checks during pregnancy and throughout the infant’s first year. Healthcare providers, including obstetrician-gynecologists, pediatricians, midwives, and doulas, should actively assess eating habits, inappropriate compensatory behaviors, and body dissatisfaction to determine determine
whether whether referral to ED specialist care is warranted.
